subject: Re: [junit] how to test abstract class
msgSnippet: ... I didn t even consider whether public or nonpublic. The odds are that such a class would only be in my test source tree, anyway, so it s not an issue. --
messageBody:
David Corbin wrote:

> On Friday 24 October 2003 12:59, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > Siamack wrote:
> > > This solution may not be ideal but it worked in my case. Inside my
> > > testcase I implemented a inner class that extends my abstract class and
> > > provides dummy implementation for abastract method and then I used that
> > > class to test non-abstract methods. There might be better ways. I hope
> > > this helps.
> >
> > I wouldn't necessarily make it an inner class, but that's what you need
> > to do: create a dummy implementation of the abstract class and test that.
>
> Do you mean that literally, or do you mean "you'd probably NOT make it a
> public class"?

I didn't even consider whether public or nonpublic. The odds are that
such a class would only be in my test source tree, anyway, so it's not
an issue.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
